This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: A GERMAN VIEW OF AMERICA.
div.p: Two books on America have recently appear- éd in German: "Americana," by Karl Lamprecht, the distinguished jurist of the University of Leipzig, an unpretentious volame by Ludwig Fulda, the poet and novelist. This is "the sympathetic review of a witty and equally sharp-eyed critic, upon whom the friendly sum shone on the first day of his arrival in New York, and continued to shine, with rare exceptions, until his reluctant departure for Europe. Fulda," says the New York "Nation," "came to America with a free and receptive mind, . and yielded himself completely to whatever impressions his'environment should make...... "That which most exceeds all expectations of the author, however, is the extent.of popu- Jar education in America, and our systems of public and higher instruction. Every one here jis hungry to learn, reading is more general than in any other country,and libraries surpass in number and practical organisation, as well as sometimes in magnificent buildings, anythingknown abroad. 'Every American, from millionaire to shoeblack, and from professor to schoolboy, is a fanatical newspaper reader,' because of and notwithstanding 'the 'horrible headlines,' This fact may account for the importunate artists and women reporters, who more than once insisted on interviewing him at his morning toilet,'in the name of the newspaper, of course' ; and for the piracy of foreign literature, calling for revision of the American copyright laws.

"Fulda observes with natural satisfaction the wide study of German by Americans He attends classes and chapel, lectures and dines at colleges for women, and-is delighted with the opportunity afforded the girls in America for advanced study, regarding their way: of living and preparing for the duties of life superior to that of the average young woman in Germany dancing away herexistence. He is inclined to believe that Schiller's exhortation, 'Ehret die Frauen |' is observed by Germans rather in theory than in practice, more in words than in deeds. He prefers coeducation to the" habit abroad of separating the sexes so long, praises the free relations between American professors and their students, and has a good word' generally for student life among our young men, with their concerts and student plays.He . feels a satisfactionin the absence of scarred and bloated faces, and holds that even the excesses of athletics are better than duel and the 'Mensar.'

"He finds no genuine American art, notwithstanding a popular artistic feeling, museums, and academies ; and he thinks that individual, creative art is wanting because the American, alive to decorate his house, has not yet learned to adorn his life with art. Hard work, elaborate not perceived how great a force for good the theatre in right hands. may become, and no American philanthropist has endowed. the stage. In condemning the oft-repeated performance of the same play, Fulda errs in saying that Jefferson played the one role all his life."

div.p: An_ isolated case of cholera is reported from Mecca.

div.head: Now Quay Appointment.
div.p: » Mohamed Effendi Khatta, Ministry of Just: ice, has been appointed Superintendent of the Alexandria quays.

div.head: The Coldstream Cuarde.
div.p: The annual sports of the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will be held on the Slade ground, Abbassia, on Thursday next.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: There aré now 19 cases of plagne under treatment, One case has been discharged cured and one has ended fatally at: Alexandria.

div.head: Hasheesh Smuggling.
div.p: The Coast 'Guards Administration -seized 106 kilos and 850 grammes of hasheesh in the Port Said' harbour on the 12th inst. this being the second seizure made at Port Said within the fortnight.

div.head: Cairo Water Commission.
div.p: A Council of Ministers will be heldthis week, and the report of the special water commission will be one of the subjects submitted to the Council. We understanéthat this report is in every way a favourable one.

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Cairo.
div.p: The first small dance of the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be held next Saturday. Tables for dinner and supper should be booked early as numerous, orders haye already been given. The Old Rugbeian Dinner will also be held at the Savoy on the same evening.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: Members Of the Cairo Scientific Society are invited to inspect the Rodah Bridge by invita- tion of Mr. A. J: Knowles, on Thursday next. A paper will be read before the Society by Mr. Knowles, at a later date, describing * the construction of the Bridge.

div.head: Y. W. 6. A. Cairo.
div.p: The sale of work of the Young Women's Christian Association, Cairo, which will be opened at 3.30 p.m. to-morrow by Lady Gorst at the Semiramis Hotel, will be re-opened at the same hour on the following day by Lady Blanche Smith at-Connaught House;

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and December 1.291,617 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 711,207 tons wete Welsh, 158,579 12 * Noweastle, 186,149 Yorkshire, 100,080 Scotch and 135,602 other qualities. During the corres- ponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,217,384:

div.head: Nativé Criminal Court.
div.p: The Criminal Court of Alexandria which met-on the 14th inst. under the presidency of Judge- Mohamed Bey Said, Councillor to the Court of Appeal,.have sentenced Akeel Saad, Saad Ahmed, and *Abnbaker Massad, who murdered the Omdeh of Zarka village, to im prisonment with hard labour for life.

div.head: Bandmann's Comedy Company.
div.p: Maurice E. Bandmann has arranged for his London Comedy Company.to appear for two weeks at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, in the latter part of April and beginning of May next. The company has carried every- thing before it during their eighteen months -tour in India and the Far East. While in Cairo they will give the following popular London successes :— "Raffles," "His House in Order," 'The Walls of Jericho,' "The Christ- ian." 'The Morals of Marcus," "John Glade's Honour," "Che Admirable Crichton," 'Peter's Mother," "Old Heidelberg," "Sherlock Holm- es," "The Earl of Pawtucket," and "Sunday." The repertoire is certainly an excellent one and seding that the company 1s carrying some fifty tons of scenery we are likely to see each piece staged in the same elaborate mauner as in London.

div.head:
Alexandria Conservatoire of music
ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE OF MUSIC.
div.p: The fifth annual entertainment given by the } pupils of the above flourishing institution took place on Saturday in the Lifontr concert hall, and' attracted*a large and' fashionable "audience. Most ofthe items showed a dec idedl improvement on last year's. pe 'rformance, which was more particnlarly marked in the individual numbers. The choruses might be much more forcibly. rendered. appeared to be an absence of any attempt at accentuate the light and shade which 1s 80 necessary in order to produce the' effects in- tended in such achorosas Verdi's "I Profughi Scozzesi" trom Macbeth.

The same remark applies to the chorus "'La Primavera" in*the sécond part. The soprano solo in this, Azzarelli, whose perfofmance was rather spoil- ed, however, by an evident nervousness. In Mayerbeer's romance "Sic Vendicata' Prof, Gianni Galletti put forward one -of his best pupils in Sig. D.Lambridis,who has a fine yoice. of excellent.quality and his tasteful rendering was much appreciated. Schumann's duet "for soprano and tenor "La Danza" was pleasingly he instrumental numbers. were particularly good. Sig. Perdichidis and ig. R.. Scinica gave violin, solos in @ manner which was most comméndable. Messtfs. Te: and J. Papasian are worthy of more than passing notice: each worked hard and contributed considerably to thé suecess of the enter- tainment. We congratulate. Signore. Gianni Galletti. Lama, Colella, Romeo, and Onesti, on the excellent progress made by the pupils.

div.head:
Companies in Egypt
SUPREME COURT'S DECISIONS.
div.p: Judge Cator in the Supreme British Consular Court~delivered judgment this morning on the two appeals of the Bourse and Banking Company Ltd against the judgments of the Consular Court given on the 20th November last. The Appeal Court dismissed both appeals and ordered the Bourse and Banking Company to pay the costs in the Court below and on the appeals.

These decision of the Supreme Court to up- hold the judgments of the lower Court, given on the 20th ulto., are of great importance as all thie numérous limited liabilities companies, registered under the companies Acts, «whose sphere of operations are in Egypt, are now declared to be amenable to the jurisdiction of the British Consular Courts, whether their boards are composed of subjects of foreign Powers or not. In the one case an application was made by an English shareholder of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited, represented by Mr. Gooding for the removal of the liquidator, appointed at the meeting of the shareholders and the appointment of a liquidatornominated by the Court. Mr. Devon- shire, who represented the company contended that the court had (4) no jurisdiction onder section 12 of the Order in Council, (2) no jurisdiction in that the circumstances do not admit of same under section 107 of the Order unless, under section 167, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs should make an order covering a case where the circumstances do not permit.

The Court held that the question at issue fell Within jurisdiction as the plaintiff isa British subject and the defendant compuny of the same nationality,whereby the Mixed Courts could have no jurisdiction. Council for the defence appealed to the Supreme Court, which has now decided that the Court had jurisdiction.

In the second case, the plaintiff, an English shareholder in the same company, represented by Mr. Reginald Silley, brought an action on the tollowing grounds. The plaintiff had been allotted 200 shares in the Company which he sold at a premium of #5. Subsequently, on the announcement that the bearer warrants were ready, plaintiff applied through the Anglo- Egyptian Bank for delivery of same. He was requested by the company to sign a form in accordance with the regulations of the Alexandria Bourse, or otherwise the company would not make the delivery. The plaintiff filled up the form, expunging the words "according to the Alexandria Bourse require- ments." Mr. Silley sabmitted that such con- dition in the form was unfair and interfered with 'the rights of private contract and, therefore, the company is improperly retaining the warrants. Mr. Devonshire, for the company contended that art. 47 of the company's sta- tutes fully empowered the directors to de- termine the conditions upon which* the bearer warrants should be issued and to settle the form of application for the same. The. lower Court held that the directors were not justified in attaching such condition and gaye judg- ment for the plaintiff for the delivery of the warrants or £200 and costs. The Bourse and Banking Company, appealed against this decision, but, as already announ- ced, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeai.
The full bearings of these decisions will be considered in another issue.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE

div.head: PILGRIMS AT BEYROUT
div.p: 'DISTINGUISHED PASSENGERS. (FROM uUR OWN CORRESPONDENT. )

Beyrout, December 12. The Khedivial Mailliner S.8. "Tantah' arrived yesterday from Constantinople with a contin- gent of pilgrims for Mecca among whom were the following distinguished personages: the mother of the present Shah of Persia, Sultan Mobam- med Ali, and his brother Prince Nasreddine Mirza, with a large retinue of Ulemas etc. The Prince is only eleven~ years of age and is said to be endowed with remarkable intelligence. After the official visits to the Seraglio and the Per- sian Consulate General, his Highness stopped: with his mother as honoured guests at the Vali's residence for the night and then proceeded by the some boat next day toCaiffa,where they are to take the Hedjaz Railway for the sacred towns. The S;. "Tantah" took from Beyrout 315 pilgrims.

div.head:
Egyptian Politics
THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.
div.p: The formation of an. Egyptian, Repebliean Nationalist party is still exciting a good deal of discussion, for the demand for thé' immedia te constitution of an' antonomous' automatic, and independent republic of Egypt has at- tracted a good deal of notice. A vernacular contemporary remarks :—

It appears now that. the leader of this. new movement is an editor. who acted as assistant and counsellor to thesupposed leader. of the Egyptian Liberals. Well, liberalism bas in many ¢éases led to republicanism and even to socialism, and we are .in the same boat with other nations. But who is the candidate for the presidency according to present arran- gements?
THE COPTIC. PARTY

"Al Watan," the Coptic Cairo organ, in'a notice of the Coptic party, says :— ~ The coptic party was given® the death blow by the refusal of "Al-Watan" to" work=for ite constructions; Yet some:individuals talk ofits coming formation and say that it will not insiat upon the public useof the ancient Coptic language as the basis-of its political mission.
THE NATIONALIST EXTREMISTS.

The general assembly of the active-members of the National Party will take place atthe "Lewa" office on Friday the 27th. inst) in order to select. the committee of direction: and to approve the statutes. "Our Direetor," says the "Egyptian Standard," "will deliver-an im« portant political discourse. on the-occasion."
PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.

A Cairo correspondent writes :— Great indignation has been aroused among. the various political parties in Cairo atthe, news that Abdul Razik Pasha has had a mani-, festo published in the London "Standard," outlining the aims of the Party of the People. The other parties of "'Nationalistic" proclivities, recognise that the handful of political busy- bodies in England, who take an interest.in, Egypt, will soon be so confased as to the state of affairs here that they will be quite unable to know which 'Party' topatronise. The Moderate Nationalists and the Egyptian Liberals have:} each had various maniféstoes published in the, London newspapers and now that the Party of the People has secured a footing in the English; Press, it will be difficult for the Radi¢als to. distinguish one party from the other, especially as they are all, collectively and individually, anathematised by Mustapha Pasha Kamel. The leader of the Nationalist Extremists is very, much chagrined at Abdul Razik Pasha's in auguration of a forward policy in the London Press, for not only hus he lost the' patronage of Mr. Robertson, M:P.~ and' Aborigines Pro- tection Society, but he has seen his influence in England undermined by the Moderates and the recent' foundation of the party of the Constitutional Reformers-has: still further in- creased his vexation. NoW.even the Party of the People, which he always affected to despise, has gained a hearing. in Exgland and of eourse every tresh party helps to diminish his in- fluence as the sole and supreme head of the National Movement.

div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: This morning the case of Emin Bey Azmy v. Liquidators of the Cassa di Sconto came on for hearing before the Mixed Commercial Court, Alexandria. The Counsel for the liquidators at the opening of the case raised the point of a "fin de non recevoir." Maitre Mercinier, counsel for the plaintiff, declared that it was quite inadmissible for the counsel for the defence to open a case. The President of the Court agreed to this and Maitre Meroinier opened the case by giving a review of the failure and of its results. He pointed out that he had despatched an "acte d'assignation" to Maitre Guidotti, the liquidators' counsel, and the latter had refused to furnish him with the documents necessary for his case. Consequently he had to base his case on his client's memoranda. The case is proceeding as we go to press. A large number of brokers were in court.

div.head: THE STAMATOPULO CASE.
div.p: This morning the application of Mr. Luigi Stagni in the case of Stamatopoulo Brothers to prevent the granting of the "concordat préventif" and to declare the firm bankropt was refused by the Mixed Commercial Court, which granted a "concordat" as the balance sheet had been deposited within the legal time.
The cause list of this court this morning, included 160 cases, many of which were bankruptcies.

div.head: RE JEAN PANYOTTOU.
div.p: This application for a "concordat préventif" was granted by this Court.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING CO.
div.p: The same Court heard an appeal.case by this company against being ordered by a preceeding judgment to pay 3 to 4 months' salary to its dismissed employés, and asked to be al lowed to pay one month's indemnity. Maitre Keun, counsel for the respondents, proved that it was not a case of "force majeure" as the appellants declared Judgment will be deliver ed in a week's time.

EXCHANGE OF SPECIE. The total of specie imported last month was L.E.1,159,237 as compared with L E.1,082,882 in November 1906. During the first eleven months of the year the import of specie was LLE. 1,269,372 as compared with L.E. 2,561,743 in the corresponding period of last year. Of the LE. 7,269,372 imported between January 1 | and November 30, L.E. 4,758,738 came from England and L E. 1,313,726 from Turkey.

The specie exported during last month was IIE. 34,038 as compared with L E. 11,985 in November 1906, and for the eleven months period the figures are L.E. 4,697,869 and L.E. 2,026,992 respectively for 1907 and 1906. Of the exported specie in eleven months L.E. 2,118,215 went to England L.E. 1,713,850 to India, L.E. 482,160 to Turkey, and L.E.340,036 to France.

CIGARETTE TRADE. The total export of cigarettes during November was 39,944 kilos, as compared with 39,811 in Nov. 1906 and from the 1st of January to 30th November the figures recorded for 1907 and 1906 respectively are 446,914 kilos, and 543,807 kilos. Of the 446,914. kilos, exported during the past ten months 139,572 went to Germany; 78,432 to England; 63,045 to British possessions in the Far East; 39,529 to Austro-Hungary ; 33,615 to Norway and Swe. den ; 22,839 to China and the Far East; 21,536 to France; 18,410 to America; and 10,492 to Belgium

div.head: STEAM PLOUGHS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: The "Machinery Market," the London machinery trade organ remarks :

In view of the agricultural activity in Egypt and the promise of development in the Sudan, the demand for agricultural machinery is not surprising. Reaping and threshing machines have not yet been generally adopted, but older methods are certainly passing away. Among the numerous land companies which are re. claiming the soil, a market exists for steam ploughs and levelling plant, and although British makes in this line are supreme, their supply could be more largely developed by the services of energetie and qualified representa tives. Centrifugal pumps have for years been in use in Egypt in all work connected with irrigation, sugar faetories, drainage, and mine sinking For fixed and portable engines there is a corresponding demand and preference is shown for those which are economical in fuel consumption.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellermap liner "City of Khios" sailed for Liverpool direct last Saturday evening with a full cargo, including 5,425 bales of cotton. | The Westcott liner Orchis" sailed from Malta last Saturday noon and is due here with general cargo on Wednesday morning.

div.head:
AUTOMOBILE GYMKHANA.
COMPETITIONS IN CAIRO
div.p: Nearly every motor in Cairo was to be seen on the Pyramid Road on Sunday, from the pioneer puffing-billy of archaic days to the latest importation from the most up-to-date garage, and the track from Mena House to the race course was a regular death trap to the unwary pedestrian. The Gymkhana attracted a goodly number of spectators though perhaps owing to the day the English contingent was not so numerous as those of other nationalities. Mena House was well patronized during the lunch hour, many big parties being noticed both in the dining ball and adjoining room ; and the terrace and verandah were crowded with thirsty tea drinkers at the conclusion of the afternoon's events. The band of the K.O.S.B's was in attendance, and the programte of music was a very pleasing feature of the entertainment. The events themselves were of a most entertaining and interest ing nature, and were watched with keenest zeal throughout the afternoon. In many instances the owners acted as chauffeurs, and much of the driving was exceptionally fine. The races were after the usual gymkhana type, calculated to display the full resources of the cars and their chanffeurs, and speed for once playing a very secondary part to trained skill and delicacy in manipulation.

In the first event the drivers had to cast arrows while their cars were in motion, advan. cing and reversing in succession, and this was won by Mr. Alex. Comanos with his fine Cotterean, F. de Martino Bey coming in second and Aly Bey Fouad third.

The second event was for driving through a very narrow passage ont-lined by ninepins, and required the very greatest skill. Aly Bey Fouad came in first, Mr. Alex. Comanos second, and Imadeddyn Bey third.

The third event was perhaps the most exciting of the programme, necessitating the greatest judgment and most delicate manipulation. The cars had to be driven on to a long wooden sea-saw, the prize going to the car that remained at the exact balance for the greatest number of seconds. It was extraordinary to watch some of these enormous and unwieldly looking antomobiles crawling slowly up the incline and until they hung true in the balance ; and there was an immense amount of enthusiasm aroused by the ingenuity of some competitors, to adjust their machines to the exact spot. Mr. A. Suerès proved eventually the winner, Aly Bey Fouad coming in second, and Mr. Ch. Baehler's dramatic finale availed him nothing. | The fourth event required a lady's assistance, each chauffeur being attended by a lady who had to pick up cárds from certain stands while | the car was in motion and place them on a third stand, Mr. A. Snarès was again successfol here with the deft assistance of Miss Nungovich, and Mr. A. Nungovich scored second with Miss Voronoff beside him.
The prize for the slowest moving motor was won by F. De Martino Bey, M Kourchid Bey coming in second. This event was ran (or recher crawled) oft in two heats.

Many people had left the ground before the | final event, which was entered by all the motor "antikas" in the neighbourhood. There were motors that puffed and shook and groaned to bursting pitch ; some that refused to move at all, one that purported to have travelled from Pekin to Cairo, and looked as if it spoke the troth, and another that was harnessed behind a stalwart camel. There were motors plastered over with sensational announcements, and motors badly in need of many coats of paint ; and in fact the final view of the race track might have been the very nightmare of a motor maniac.

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS.
THE CASE OF SAFWAT.
div.p: | TO THE EDITOR OF Tue "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.-- In reference to the revelations as to the Ports and Lights Administration for which I have suffered unjustly, I beg to point out to all whom it may concern, that when my advocate obtained from the Parquet the copy of the sentence of the Council of Discipline in my case, I found that my dismissal from the Government Service as chief Inspector of the quay Office at Alexandria was said to be based on the fact that the revenue of the Quay office, which in 1903 was L.E. 7,055, fell in 1904 to L.E. 4,050. I now want to point out that the actual revenue in 1903 was L.E. 3,681 | and in 1904 L.E. 4,498. If the accounts of the Quay Office are revieed it will at once be seen
that I have not been treated justly by the -Committee of Enquiry.
Truly Yours,
M. SAFWAT. E| (Bimbashi, Late Chief Inspector of the Alex andria Quays, Ports and Lights Administration.)

Dear Sir,-- In the notiee calling the Extra1 ordinary General Meeting of this Company for

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun and Mahmoud Pasha Moukhtas, have arrived in Alexandria from Cairo.
Lady Gorst will not be "at home" on Saturday afternoong until farther notice.
Mustafa Pasha Ibabi, Governor of Alexan. dria, left for Cairo yesterday.

Prince Leopold of Battenberg, who is well known in Egypt by reason of his extended visits, is appearing as a servant, Roger, in the production of "She Stoops to Conquer," which is being given by the Cambridge A.D.C.

Among the approaching arrivals at Cairo are Sir John Harrington, British Minister to Abyssinia, who, accompanied by Lady Harrington, left London last week, via Paris and Rome, en route for Adis Abeba, and will visit Cairo on the way.
Countess Gleichen left for Europe, on Saturday afternoon by the S.S "Heliopolis". Lady Valda Machell came to Alexandria to see her off and returned in the evening to Cairo.
Lord Norreya, elder son and heir of the Earl of Abingdon, has arrived at Alexandria and is staying at the Savoy Palace Hotel.
Lady Alexander Paget and Lady Beatrice Herbert are arriving in Egypt shortly.
Mr. Ronald Graham has returned to the British Agency, Cairo.

Don Fernando de Osorio y Elola, the newly appointed Envoy Extraordinary, Minister Plenipotentiary, Agent and Consol General of H. M. the King of Spain, has arrived in Cairo and is staying at the Hotel d'Angleterre.

Mr. Alfred Curphey, one of the members of the board of directors of the Egyptian Ma il S.S. Company, who arrived by the S.S. "He. liopolis" on Tuesday, returned on Saturday by the same steamer and intends to return to Egypt for the season by the SS. "Cairo" in
January

Among the newly wed who are coming to Egypt on their honeymoon are Captain Rose and his wife. Last week in York, Minster Captain Adrian Rose, Royal Horse Guards, son of Mr. Charles Day Rose, M.P. for the Neymar, ket Division of Cambridgeshire, of 53, Berke| ley-square, and Hardwick House, Reading, was married to Miss Nancy Lycett-Green, daughter of Mr. Edward Lycett-Grean, of Ashfield, York, and granddaughter of Sir Edward Green, of Nunthorpe Hall, York, and of Mr. Arthur Wilson, of Tranby Croft. They intend spending their honeymoun at Assouan.
The latest arrivals at the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh, inelade Count Malcolm Hamilton, Edward Bey Elias, Mr. and Mrs. Rouse, Mr. H. P. Hitchcock, Mr. W. Bartholomew, and Miss Bartholomew.

The following are passengers by Cook's P.S. "Prince Abbas," which leaves Shellal to-day :| Dr. and Mrs. W. A. E. Weidner, Mr. and Mrs. Peroy Withers, Mr. V. L. Lescornez, Mr. Hubert Dufour, Miss Alison Gailand, Dr. D.G. Elliot, Miss M. H. Elliot, Miss Rose Morgan, Miss Kate Woodward, Dr. and Mrs. W. Weis. gerber, Mr. and Miss H. Bonham Carter, Mr. E. Bonham Carter, Capt. and Mrs. Mc. Arthur Onslow, Miss E. Onslow, Mrs. Porges.

div.head: SALE OF WORK
div.p: Under the auspices of the "Scots School Fellow Workers' Union," a sale of work was held in the St. Andrew's High School on Friday last, 13th inst. The sale was opened by Miss Collins, D.C.S., who is an honorary member of the Work Party. In declaring the sale open she commended the object to all present, the proceeds going to charity among deserving cases of poor Jewish families, among whom the work of the Church of Scotland Mission is carried on.

On the various stalls, which were presided over by Mesdames Buchanan, Gibb, Goodrick, Heaton and Thom, Misses Coutts and Gibson, assisted by the young ladies of the work party, was a large and varied assortment of goods, which, from the ready and rapid sale met with, seemed quite to suit the taste of those who patronised the sale.
The sale room and stalls were tastefully decorated with evergreens and flowers kindly sent by Mrs. Lang Anderson, Mrs. J. Davies Bryan, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Robinson and Mrs.
Tennant. As an attraction instrumental musio I was contributed by Miss Vaccari and Mr. 0.
Stanley Heaton, and songs were rendered by Miss Davies and Mr. Wm. Thom. It is satisfacitory to note that there was a very successful sale, the stalls being almost entirely cleared:

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: (Anjourd hui 2 midi)

Le marché a présenté la méme aspect que la semaine passée, c'est-a-dire sans animation et avec unchiffre d'affairesexcessivement restreint. A part quelques échanges insignifiants et clair-. semés en Comptoir, Delta Land et quelques / autres valeurs, on n'a traité quela Khédivial Mail qui a été offerte sur le marché par milliers. Les ordres de venteprovenaient principalement da Caire. Cependant; comme il s'est trouvé des acheteurs pour absorber toutes les offres, le prix, apres avoir fiéchi de '1 shelling, est re- montéen cléture 4 20/6 acheteurs, soit en dé- finitive une perte de 6 pence en tout:pour la séance.
La Delta Land, la New-Egyptian, }'Aboukir, la Port Said Salt et la Salt & Soda étaient oftertes.

Quant aux titres dirigeants, ils ont été négli- gés, comme cela ressort de:leur cotation 4 des prix légtrement — inférieurs A ceux de vendredi passé. C'estainsi que l'Agricole rétrograde de, 77/8 a 718/16, la National Bank de 20 1/4 a 20 3/16 et.la Delta Light de 9 3/4 a 9 11/16, T'Obligation Crédit Foncier fiéchit' aussi de 287.4285 1/2 V'ancienne et de 2524251 1/2 la nonvelle, mais ces nouveaux cours s enten- dant ex-tirage, il n'y a pas de baisse propre- ment dite.
L' Alexandria Water recule de 10.7/8 a 10 3/4 ex-coupon, la Banque d'Athénes de 118 1/2 4 113, la Privilégiée Khedivial Mail de 4 1/4a 4 1,8, et la Banque d'Orient de 1123/4 & 112.

Parmi les titres de moindre envergure, .la Salt & Soda. tombe de 14/3 a 14/-, les Sucre- ries de 34 4 33, le Comptoir de 27/16 4 2 3/8, l'Aboukir de 28/9 a 28/-, Ja Port Said Salt de 12/3 & 12/-, la Fanous dé 5/16 a 9/82, ainsi a la Levico. L'Urbaine remonte de 3 1/8 a 3 3/16
Ila été vendu aux enchéres publiques a6 Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte a 2 13/32 et 19 Obligations, Crédit Foncier Egyp- tien dont 17 nouvelles 4 252 et 2 anciénnes & 290 1/2.

En vue d'éviter de nouveaux frais d'admi- nistration, un groupe de porteurs de parts Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh de- mande au conseil d'administrafion de «porter & l'ordre du jour de la prochaine assemblée générale annuellé la question de la liquidation | et répartition de l'actif existant. Une pétition dans ce sens, couverte de signatures, va étre -expédiée 4 S.S8. Harari Pacha . qu'on propose comme liquidateur. Une demande analogue 'avait déja été formalée l'année derniére, mais n'ayant pas été faite dans les délais prescrits | ® par les statuts, elle avait été rejutée.

div.head:
WEATHER' IN ENGLAND.
GALES AND RAINS.
SHIPPING DISASTERS.

div.p: A farious gale has been blowing since yester- day evening. There have been many wrecks and loss of life on the South coast. A seven- masted American schooner has been wrecked at Scilly and 18 people drowned A _ pinnace belonging to H.M.S. "Speedwell" was capsized at Sheerness and 8 men drowned. Cross-Chan- nel trafic has been interrupted and telegraph wires are down. Torrential rains have caused the Thames and.Severn to overflow and large tracts of land are inundated. Extraordinary scenes are. witnessed all along the Thames valley. .( Reuter)

div.head:
AMERICA AND JAPAN.
A SENSATIONAL STORY:
SERVANTS AS SPIES.

div.p: The newspapers publish" sensational stories stating that all Japanese servants have been landed from the battleships of the Pacific fleet in the Hampton Roads because they were constantly taking notes. One was detected noting a new system of guncontrol. (Reuter)

div.head:
TREASON IN RUSSIA.
DUMA EX- ee ON TRIAL.

div.p: In the treason trial against the Social De- inocrats, 7 ex-members of the second Duma have been acquitted and 80 exiled to Siberia The Socialist group of the Doma tended violently towands a democratic republic. (Havas)

The trial of Socialists, including 37 ex-mem- bers of the Duma, for treason here has resulted in most drastic sentences. 80 of the ex-Du- maites are to be permanently exiled in Siberia, 22 of them receiving, in addition, varions terms of imprisonment. (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMANY AND HOLLAND.
THE KAISER'S SENTIMENTS.

div.p: The German Emperor, replying to Queen Wilhelmina's toast, said that he would stake his life on the maintenance. of peace between Germany and Holland. He referred to the Netherlands as the land where his ancestors had learned their duty to their country. (Reuter )

Mouse of Representatives. Mr. Deakin, out- lining the defence policy of the Government, said that it was proposed to purchase three submarines and two destroyers annually for three years. Military training was to be com- pulsory for all youths attaining the age of 18. "He hoped that a national guard of 218,000 trained men wai) 'be available in eight years. ( Reuter)
The Duke and Duchess of Connanght will embark at Marseilles on 2nd January: for Malta. : ( Reuter )

div.head:
THE PERSIAN PARLAMENT.
RESIGNATION OF CABINER,

div.p: The Cabinet resigned yesterday in conse- quence of incidents arising ont ofthe murder of two shop keepers by soldiers, who were im- prisoned bat whose immediats execution was demanded by the relatives of the victims and the Anjumans. A great crowd, partly armed, assembled near the Parliament buildings. The bazaars were closed and ball cartridges were served out tothe Palace quards and garrison The Shah summoned Nizam Sultaneh and Nizam el Malk.

(Later). Parliament has been informed that the ex-Premier and ex-Minister of the Interior have been arrested by order of the Shah The House has demanded an explanation from the Sovereign, refusing to quit the building before & reply was received. The crowd is also wait- ing. It is believed that the Shah is acting on the advice of the reactionary members ( Reuter)
1,200 troops made a demonstration in the Usutu Valley. The Zulus were surprised and offered no resistance. The search for fire arms has been without result. (Reuter)

Dini Zulu has started for Durban. Colonel Mackenzie's troops have returned to Nongoma after marching throngh the disaffected areas. They discovered a number of young Usutu tribesmen with rifles who were missing. (Reuter)
Ten of the principal natives accompanying Dini Zulu have been arrested on suspicion of sedition. (Reuter)

A Jarge column has left to punish the Beni- Snassens.. ~* , (Havas) Oran, December 15. A French column 3,000 strong has moved out of Lalaparmania, operating against the Snassen tribesmen who are posted in the hills, (Reuter)
Abd el Aziz has given France and Spain the orderto repress contraband of arms in Morocan waters, (Havas) T'anarer, December 15. M. Regnault has returned. (Havas)
2,000 Montenegrins have crossed the frontier near Gusinie and massacred the inhabitants of two Albanian villages. ( Reuter)

Important developments are imminent in Finland. General Kaulbars, ex-Governor of Odessa, will be appointed Governor-General and a strong military force is proceeding there, ostensibly for manwuyres. The Government is apparently resolved to crush the revolutionary, organisations. (Reuter)
Cricket. At lurich time Australia's score was os runs for 2 wickets. (Reuter) Sypyry, December 14. Cricket Australia 300. England second in- (Reuter)

div.head: Headaches and Neuralgia.
div.p: THE EFFICACY OF DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

Mme Octave Mignolet, whose portrait is given herewith, lives in the Rue Longue, Ostend. She suffered trom a variety of ailments, and particularly sick headaches and acute neafalgia, Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People had an excellent effect on her nervous system, and now she has ceased to suffer from neuralgia and headaches, and enjoys splendid health.

"I was always in pain," she writes, "and there never was a night when I could look back and say that I had passed a pleasant day. I was out of gorts and not at all strong. What | ~. ra "| fatiened me more than anything else were sick headaches, which I had almost every day, while sometimes I had neuralgia for weeks at a stretch. My life became insupportable, for I could scarcely get a moment's sleep. I resorted to all sorts of devices to get some rest, but my neuralgia was an obstacle to all my efforts, and the nights passed without my having slept atall Of course, I tried many medicines, but none of them did me any good, until I gave Dr. Williams' Pink Pills a trial, having.read of their efficacy ina newspaper. These pills cured me, ahd my existence is now quite changed." The prediliction for sick headaches in the weaker sex is proverbial. div.head: COTTON IN. THE LEVANT.
div.p: GERMANY'S PLANS.
(From Ovr Owy CoRRESPONDENT.)

Beyrouth, 9th December. The publication by Reuter's Agency of the} important intelligence of the final conclusion of details of the Konia Irrigation Scheme has brought once more Asia Minor with its _poli- tical and vast economic possibilities, before the eyes of Europe and will continue to be the chief subject of discussion and comment. A few particulars therefore about the present agricultaral and industrial activities of the outlying regions such as Mersine and' Adana may not be devoid of particular interest. In a former article ample reference was made to the recent introduction of the perfected methods of steamploughing in connection particularly with cotton cultivation and the following com- plementary notes appear to be necessary. The area under cotton cultivation in Mersine and Adana districts is estimated at about 170,000 acres and the yield ranges between forty and fifty thousand bales of 200 kilogrammes the bale. The Germans seem to have had a long time ago their eye on the cotton culture with its vast possibilities of development and it was German capital that built the first factory for ginning crude cotton and the pressing of bales according tothe system adopted in Egypt. Bales of 250 kilogrammes pressed at this factory have a much smaller volume than bales of 200 kilos, ordinarily pressed, The resulting economy in freight is obvious 'Thanks to German initiative also the seed of 'the American 'quality known as "Upland" and which is in special demand in the New Orleans markets has been introduced first as a trial and is since being gradually vulgarized considering the eminently satisfactory results In the direction of the development of agri- cultural methods on modern lines the English | sales have the largest share of initiative, and most 'if not all of the various implements lately introduced have come and still come from English firms, notably that of Messrs. John Fowler and Co. Ltd. at Leeds. There are' now in use six steamplonghs of which two with single traction and four with double traction, several orders are on the way. There are also 60 thrashing machines, and every year fairly important additions to the existing stock are made. As regards reaping machines they may be counted by hundreds and indeed their use is universal save in the mountainons parts where the primitive scythe still'survives. —
BAGHDAD RAILWAY.

But the field for gigantic enterprise is left for the Germans, and the pent up activity of | . this eminently scientific and industrious nation is destined to manifest itself ina magnificent manner and restore that virgin country to its old glory, with. the additional blessings of modern civilization, when it is likely to become a great centre of productiveness that will count as a factor in the world's economic problem. The Baghdad railway, a grandiose scheme, is being slowly elaborated and step by step it is nearing the great though distant goal. The Mersine Tarsus Adana Line which is $7 kilo- meters in length has already been bought up by the Germans and two shipments of about 1200 tons of, iron sleepers have lately been discharged by the German Atlas steamers of Bremen, to replace the old and worn out material. This small line is destined to be ultimately linked with the grand trank line which has passed already Eregli and reached Bourgulu which lies within only 160 kilometers of Mersine.

This junction which seems to be inevitable will be either at Adana or Mersine. In the first case the Baghded trunk line will it is said have to pass by Koulek Boughaz round the base of the intervening chain of mountains | and passing the valley join the M.T.A. line at Adana. In the second case the Baghdad line will have to cross the Pass of Dunkelek and join the M.T.A. line at Mersine. In either indicates organic Conkle and poverty of the blood, Dr Willian' Pick Pills for Pale People| © have a full assortment of ereate rich and pure blood with every dose ;} neW and fashionable goods for the they tonify the nervous system ; and they are| . sovereign against anemia, chlorosis: general season. debility, stomach ills, rheumatism, sick headaches, and neuralgia.

case the Taurus will have to be traversed and it is here that the greatest material obstacle in the way of the grand scheme lies. The Koulek Boughaz route involves the construction of fewer tunnels but presents on the other hand difficulty of crossing large marshy tracts. The Dunbelek route while involving more costly and difficult tan has the advantage of avoiding these tracts. The plan favoured-by the Turkish Govern. nent would cause the line to pass by Konlek | Boughaz following mére or less closely the actual carriage road which meets the Mersine Tarsous Adana line at Tarsous. The Anatolian Railway. Company. however" prefers. another | Sosa plan lying more in an easterly direction and us A ee ealoulated to bamuch shorter and less costly. , ae The trunk line in that case would follow the valley of Bozant descending through the valley an of Tchakit-Déré directly to Adana. In any case the Koulek Boughaz route would term inae other ieee are as Follows :— Ke Sa vy: eee or _—_ ol Mageaby "cana, RuoCherf Pacha, ALEXANDRIA, aleo at ate at Tarsous or rather at the station of Koulek Boughaz about 6 kilometers East of Tarsous and not at Mersine, © Apart from the p0litical interest attaching tothe Baghdad Railway the economic side thereof has incalculable importance, more so as it is bound up with the great Mesopotamian irrigation scheme. The niost indifferent cannot fail to watch with interest" the evdlution of this colossal scheme and we can only hope that the two great sister nations will ultimately find means of conciliating their political and econo- mic interests, and once an agreement is come to, the greatest of modern achievements will unfold themselves to the eyes of the word.

div.head: U.S.A. AND EGYPT.
div.p: A New York Coitmercial N ewspaper Says :— Otir part in Egypt's import trade is lamentably small. Int1906, according to "Daily Con- sular and Trade Reports, that country's im-| ports amounted to $116,596,715, and our share was only $3,042,275, though we bought $7,660,900 worth of Egyptian goods. Oar chief were : machinery, $256,520; timber, $134,050; wronght iron and steel, $45,988, and a miscellanabus. list' of smaller items, In the year our sales increased by $609,400 over 1905, chiefly in coffee, petroledm and fertilisers. Egypt's exports in 1906 amounted to $124,336,400. For our $7,660,900 we got cotton ($7,376,870), cereals, dried roots, hides and skins,rags and paper, sugar and gum arabic, in' small consignments. In August, 1906, a Cairo dealer in American. oe furniture ordered some articles from the United neous Cricket & Foot Be a 1G States and sent four-fifths cash with the order, oe but in April, 1907, he was still without. the Boxing | oods.
